[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result(), unwrap_err_result()] [Struct field ordering] Do unwrap_result() and unwrap_err_result() assume a specific field ordering in the Struct (tag first, then value), and can this ordering be violated to cause field confusion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result()] [Iterator reuse] Can the iterator returned by unpack_with_tag() be reused across multiple unwrap operations, potentially allowing the same Result value to be unwrapped multiple times and violating move semantics? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result(), unwrap_err_result()] [Tag position validation] Do these functions validate that the variant tag is actually the first element in the Struct, or can malformed Structs with the tag in a different position cause incorrect unpacking? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result()] [Invariant violation handling] When unwrap_result() line 34-35 returns PartialVMError with invariant_violation, does this error propagate correctly through the VM's error handling, or can it be caught and suppressed by malicious native functions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_err_result()] [Error message injection] In unwrap_err_result() line 45-46, the error message 'invalid result value: expected Err(_)' is static - can this message be exploited for information disclosure about internal VM state or contract logic? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: is_ok_result_ref()] [Error propagation] Does is_ok_result_ref() properly propagate errors from value_as::<StructRef>() and test_variant(), or can certain error conditions be silently swallowed causing incorrect boolean results? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result(), unwrap_err_result()] [Panic safety] Can unwrap_result() or unwrap_err_result() panic instead of returning PartialVMError under certain edge cases, causing transaction abort and potential DoS? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: is_ok_result_ref()] [Boolean return validation] Does is_ok_result_ref() guarantee it returns exactly Value::bool(true) or Value::bool(false), or can corrupted PartialVMResult propagation cause it to return other Value types? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result()] [Match arm safety] In the match statement at line 32, the '_' wildcard catches both None and Some(x) where tag != OK_VARIANT - can this conflation hide bugs where None should be handled differently than wrong-tag cases? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_err_result()] [Error code consistency] Does unwrap_err_result() use the same error code (UNKNOWN_INVARIANT_VIOLATION_ERROR) as unwrap_result(), and could this make it difficult to distinguish between different error sources during debugging or exploitation? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result(), unwrap_err_result()] [Error context loss] When these functions return PartialVMError, is sufficient context preserved about the failed unwrap operation (e.g., which Result type, from which contract) to prevent confusion in multi-contract scenarios? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: ok_result()] [Memory allocation] Does ok_result() properly handle memory allocation failures when calling Struct::pack_variant(), or can OOM conditions during Result creation cause undefined behavior or state corruption? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result()] [Value lifetime] When unwrap_result() extracts value x from the Struct and returns it, are there any dangling references or use-after-free risks if the original Struct is still referenced elsewhere? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: is_ok_result_ref()] [Reference safety] Does is_ok_result_ref() maintain proper lifetime bounds on the StructRef to prevent the reference from outliving the underlying Result value? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: err_result()] [Resource drop safety] If err_result() wraps a Value containing a Move resource, is the resource properly tracked and prevented from being dropped incorrectly when the Result is later destructed? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result(), unwrap_err_result()] [Double unwrap prevention] Can a single Result value be passed to both unwrap_result() and unwrap_err_result() in sequence, potentially allowing double-extraction of values and violating linear type semantics? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: ok_result(), err_result()] [Value clone safety] When pack_variant() is called with a vec![val], does it move or clone the value, and could this affect resource safety if val contains a resource that shouldn't be cloned? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: ok_result(), err_result()] [Gas metering bypass] Do ok_result() and err_result() properly account for gas costs of Struct::pack_variant() operations, or can attackers create deeply nested Result values with minimal gas consumption? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result(), unwrap_err_result()] [Unpacking gas costs] Are gas costs properly charged for unpack_with_tag() operations in unwrap_result() and unwrap_err_result(), or can repeated unwrapping be used for DoS attacks? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: is_ok_result_ref()] [Reference traversal gas] Does is_ok_result_ref() charge gas for value_as::<StructRef>() and test_variant() operations, or can attackers spam Result type checks to consume VM resources without paying gas? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result()] [Iterator gas costs] Does the iterator created by unpack_with_tag() at line 30 properly track and charge gas for each .next() call, or can large Result types be unpacked with insufficient gas charging? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: ok_result(), err_result()] [Pack variant cost] Is the gas cost of pack_variant() proportional to the size and complexity of the wrapped value, or can attackers pack huge values into Result types while bypassing gas metering? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: unwrap_result()] [Cross-contract type confusion] Can a malicious contract pass a Result<T1, E1> to a function expecting Result<T2, E2>, and will unwrap_result() detect this type mismatch or allow T1 to be interpreted as T2? [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/framework/move-stdlib/src/natives/result.rs] [Function: err_result()] [Error injection across modules] Can err_result() be used by a malicious module to create fake error Results that impersonate error conditions from trusted system modules like aptos_framework? (High)
